qas.question: What subdivision of anthropology seeks to understand the process of human communications?
What problems does linguistic anthropology bring linguistic methods to bear on?
What is the analysis of linguistic forms and processes linked to?
What related fields do linguistic anthropologists draw on?

answers.text: sociolinguistics, pragmatics, cognitive linguistics, semiotics, discourse analysis, and narrative analysis

qas.question: What subdivision of linguistics studies human communication?
What is the analysis of of linguistic anthropology?

plausible_answers.text: sociolinguistics, pragmatics, cognitive linguistics, semiotics, discourse analysis, and narrative analysis.

qas.question: What related fields draw on linguistic anthropology?

context: <a0_0><b4_0>Linguistic<a0_0/> anthropology<b4_0/> (also called anthropological linguistics) seeks to understand the processes of human communications, verbal and non-verbal, variation in language across time and space, the social uses of language, and the relationship between language and culture. It is the branch of anthropology that brings linguistic methods to bear on <a1_0>anthropological<a1_0/> problems, linking the analysis of linguistic forms and processes to the <a2_0><b5_0>interpretation of sociocultural processes<b5_0/><a2_0/>. Linguistic anthropologists often draw on related fields including <a3_0><b6_0>sociolinguistics, pragmatics, cognitive linguistics, semiotics, discourse analysis, and narrative analysis<a3_0/>.
